bioghist.p: Sophia Wittenberg Mumford (1899-1997) was the wife and sometime editor of the critic and historian Lewis Mumford. Sophia Wittenberg, went to work after high school as a secretary and then became an editor at The Dial, where she met Lewis Mumford. After her marriage in 1921, Mrs. Mumford gave up a budding career as an editor to help further her husband's literary and academic aspirations. The couple had two children: Geddes Mumford (1925-1944) and Alison Mumford Morss (1935-1993).

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of Sophia and Lewis Mumford, consisting of family papers of the Mumford and Wittenberg families and some works by and about Lewis Mumford. Family papers include: correspondence between Lewis Mumford and his mother, between Lewis and Sophia Mumford, from Geddes Mumford to his family and others, and between the Mumfords and Evelyn Huber; letters of William Wittenberg (Sophia's father); and letters of condolence to Sophia Mumford on the death of her husband. There are also several albums of photographs of the Mumford and Wittenberg families; daybooks of E. C. Mumford (1892-1895), primarily consisting of menus; and diaries of Sophia Mumford kept between 1961 and 1980. Materials related to Lewis Mumford's work include manuscript drafts of several books: Green Memories, Findings and Keepings, The Bridge, and The Mumford-Leibovitz Letters. This section of the collection also includes Mumford's personal notes on his mother, daughter, and son; and reprints and clippings of articles on architecture, urbanism, atomic power, fascism, and many other subjects. There are also photographs and lantern slides of cities and buildings in Europe and the US; and several maps and city plans. The collection also contains papers concerning the Lewis Mumford centennial commemoration and documentation related to the disposition of and access to the Mumford papers, including Sophia Mumford's correspondence with biographer Donald Miller and with University of Pennsylvania librarians. Other materials in the collection include a manuscript on architecture by Carl Ludwig Franck; newspaper clippings about Lewis Mumford; and audio cassettes and 16' vinyl recordings of readings of Mumford's works (read by Mumford and by others).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
